article.title: data structure
article.p:
data structure
, way in which data are stored for efficient search and retrieval. Different data structures are suited for different problems. Some data structures are useful for simple general problems, such as retrieving data that has been stored with a specific identifier. For example, an online dictionary can be structured so that it can retrieve the definition of a word. On the other hand, specialized data structures have been devised to solve complex specific search problems.

The simplest data structure is the one-dimensional (linear) array, in which stored elements are numbered with consecutive
integers
and contents are accessed by these numbers. Data items stored nonconsecutively in memory may be linked by pointers (memory addresses stored with items to indicate where the “next” item or items in the structure are located). Many
algorithms
have been developed for sorting data efficiently; these apply to structures residing in main memory and also to structures that constitute information systems and
databases
. More-complex data structures may incorporate elements of simpler data structures.
